Situation1: The taxi driver ensures the cab remains neat and hygienic.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: I wiped down the backseat of my cab, making sure every surface was spotless. As a taxi driver, I prided myself on keeping my car immaculate—my passengers expected a clean, comfortable ride, and I never wanted to disappoint. Just as I finished, my phone buzzed. It was Brother Ahmed, a long-time member of my congregation. His message was urgent: he needed to meet with me today, his family was in crisis, and he didn’t know where else to turn. As an imam, I knew how much he relied on my guidance, especially in moments like this. But my next fare was already waiting, and I couldn’t afford to cancel—my family depended on every ride I gave. I stared at my phone, torn. My duty as an imam was to be there for my community, to offer comfort and counsel. But as a taxi driver, I had a responsibility to my passengers and my own family’s livelihood. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, and I sat in the driver’s seat, heart pounding, unsure which path to take.
